This year, Sky View High School welcomes Brady Fonnesbeck as a new assistant principal. Fonnesbeck, who has taught anatomy and physiology at Sky View for the past two years and has been a teacher for fifteen years, originally planned to go to medical school. However, after shadowing a teacher at Provo High School, those plans changed.

Fonnesbeck explained, ”Once I got in that classroom, everything changed for me. The deciding factor for me deciding to pursue a teaching career and not the medical profession was how much I enjoyed being around the kids and the energy they provided.”

#WEareCache #CacheDistrict

Read more about Fonnesbeck's journey here: https://www.ccsdut.org/site/default.aspx?PageType=3&ModuleInstanceID=5044&ViewID=7b97f7ed-8e5e-4120-848f-a8b4987d588f&RenderLoc=0&FlexDataID=52788&PageID=9

Seventeen years working in education has taught Jullie Payne exactly what it takes to help students succeed. Helping others reach success and making a positive impact are just two of Payne’s goals in her newest position as North Park Elementary School’s principal.

Payne has been working in Cache County School District for the past 12 years. Holding positions as a paraprofessional, 3rd- and 5th-grade teacher, literacy facilitator, and most recently as the district’s ESL Specialist, has given her a unique perspective on the various aspects that help make education successful.

“It’s very rewarding to watch students’ confidence in themselves grow,” Payne explains. “School is a wonderful place to learn new things, make lasting memories, and continue to develop into unique, special people that can make positive impacts in the world.”

#WEareCache #CacheDistrict

To read more about North Park Elementary's new principal, visit: https://www.ccsdut.org/site/default.aspx?PageType=3&ModuleInstanceID=5044&ViewID=7b97f7ed-8e5e-4120-848f-a8b4987d588f&RenderLoc=0&FlexDataID=52770&PageID=9

Congratulations to Sadie Gallup (Canyon Elementary), Grant Richardson (North Cache MS), and Jenna Campbell (Ridgeline HS), who were the winners of a writing competition that commemorated the 100th anniversary of the 19th Amendment. The competition was sponsored by Utah Public Radio and the Cache County School District, in partnership with the Cache Celebration of Women's Suffrage 2020.

Students participating in the competition were invited to view a video about women's suffrage before responding to a prompt. The prompt said, "In no more than 800 words, share with us something the pictures in the video made you feel, imagine, or learn more about! Maybe you want to share with us a cause you think is worth “stumping” for! The page is your canvas. Be creative."

The competition winners read their essays and were interviewed on UPR'S Access Utah radio show on May 26, 2020. To listen to a recording of the show, please visit https://www.upr.org/post/womens-suffrage-essay-contest-winners-tuesdays-access-utah.

Today at approximately 2:50 pm there will be a “Salute to Utah” flyover through Logan with four fighter jets, led by Hill Air Force Base's F-35A Lightning II Demonstration team. The flyover is intended to "provide a salute to all the healthcare professionals, frontline responders, and essential personnel working to keep everyone safe and healthy during these unique times. The flyover also provides essential training to the pilots, and demonstrates the readiness of the Air Force."

The attached maps show the full route of the flyover, which loops from Ogden to St. George, passing over Cache Valley as part of the loop. Utah residents are urged to "observe the flyover from the safety of their home-quarantine and should refrain from traveling to see the flyover. Citizens should also maintain social distancing and avoid large gatherings."

Hello CCSD families,

We have been getting almost daily updates from the health department regarding COVID-19. They have asked that we thank our school community for your efforts to follow Governor Herbert’s directive to “Stay Safe, Stay Home.” These efforts are working to curb the spread of the virus and “flatten the curve,” a term we have all become familiar with during the last few weeks.

Please remember to continue to practice good hygiene and social distancing. For those of you picking up lunches at the schools or bus stops, we ask that you limit the number of your family members who come to pick up lunches and that you remain vigilant in staying the recommended six feet away from your friends and neighbors. (In Utah, this means six pans of green jello, 18 cans of diet coke laid end to end, or for you downhill skiers, a 180cm ski.) Also, we know it can be challenging, but please remind your children to keep their distance from other children and avoid playing on school playground equipment.

Thank you for helping to prevent the spread of COVID-19!

As we have been working closely with the Bear River Health Department, they have asked that we circulate the following information:

"As the escalating threat of the coronavirus pandemic continues we are pleading with families to protect their older relatives, such as grandparents, and other family members with serious underlying medical conditions. To do so, we are asking to postpone visits or trips to see these family members. Instead, write letters, make phone calls or connect through technology. Please limit your children's contact with these high-risk populations. We must protect our most vulnerable! If your child were to develop the illness their symptoms might be mild but for these vulnerable populations, it can be life-threatening. If we take these precautions seriously we will not exhaust our hospital's capacity to care for the ill." --Bear River Health Department

Please direct any health-related questions to the Bear River Health Department. A special Coronavirus Information Line has been set up at (800) 456-7707.

Congratulations to the combined Sky View/Green Canyon "We the People" team! They recently won the Utah state competition -- for the thirteenth consecutive year!

"We the People" is a program offered by the Center for Civic Education which was created to promote historical, political, and civic engagement in high school students. The program is designed as a competition, modeled after congressional hearings, presentations, and questioning. Students are tested on their knowledge of the Constitution, American history, political philosophy, and modern American citizenship in the 21st century.

We're so proud of these students and their dedication and hard work! #WEareCache #CCSDproud #CacheDistrict #uted

CCSD Kindergarten Registration will take place tomorrow, March 11th from 8:00 am - 3:00 pm, and Thursday, March 12th from 1:00 - 7:00 pm, in all CCSD elementary schools.

Registration is for children who will turn five on or before September 1, 2020. Children should be brought to be registered to their neighborhood elementary school by a parent or guardian. Children will be given a brief assessment.

Parents should bring the following documents to registration:
Child's official birth certificate
Immunization records
Parent's driver's license
Copy of a recent utility bill with current address
Copy of a recent mortgage payment or rental agreement with current address

When possible, please fill out online forms PRIOR to attending registration. These forms can be accessed on the CCSD website linked below: https://www.ccsdut.org/Page/5519 Please note that these forms work best when filled out on a computer rather than a cell phone.

Pobil, who was born and raised in Madrid before moving to Utah as a young adult, was recently named "One of Utah's Most Influential Artists." She has also been recognized as an ambassador of the Spanish culture by the King of Spain.

Muchas gracias, Señora Pobil, for visiting with our students!

Reports indicate that a snowstorm is headed our way and that the heaviest snowfall may occur during tomorrow morning’s commuting hours. We will be monitoring conditions carefully. Morning alerts to alter the same-day schedule, whether a delay or closure, will be sent by 6:00 a.m. Unless an official announcement comes from the district, parents and students should plan on schools being open and operating as usual.

In the event that schools must be delayed or closed due to inclement weather, notifications will be sent out through phone, text, and email alerts. Preferences as to how these notifications are sent can be set in PowerSchool. School closure announcements are posted on the CCSD website, as well as the district’s official Facebook page, Twitter, and Instagram. Closures and delays will also be announced on radio stations KVNU and KBLQ and on KSL’s television station.

As Cache County School District covers a large geographic area in which weather and road conditions may vary, parents have the choice to make decisions based on local circumstances and conditions.

Have you heard about GEAR UP? Gaining Early Awareness and Readiness for Undergraduate Programs (GEAR UP) is a federally-funded program designed to help students prepare for and succeed in college. Administered by USU, GEAR UP Utah provides qualifying CCSD high school students with academic support, mentoring, and guidance to help them prepare for and enroll in a post-secondary education program that meets their needs.

The four objectives of GEAR UP are to: 1) Increase academic performance and preparation for post-secondary education 2) Increase high school graduation and college enrollment rate 3) Help students find scholarships, financial aid, and other college payment options 4) Increase success in the first year of higher education.

You can find out more about GEAR UP Utah and apply today at https://gearuputah.usu.edu/.
